executive_summary: The Paper Mills industry, which produces a range of communication papers and personal care products, has contended with many obstacles to success. Heightened foreign competition from industry frontrunners and developing economies – which can produce and export at lower costs – plus a persistent decline in downstream demand for paper and paper products have hindered the industry in recent years. Paper Mills industry revenue has plummeted at a CAGR of 5.2% over the past five years and is expected to total $34.6 billion in 2024, when revenue will fall by an estimated 6.8%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Downward Trend for Demand of Paper Products was Exacerbated by COVID-19
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Many downstream buyers found themselves with less buying power and less need for paper products as corporations shut down in-office activities.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The work-from-home environment accelerated the usage of competing technologies such as electronic transmission and document storage alternatives, which further hurt demand for paper products
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Demand for certain personal care products increased as consumers pantry-loaded during the initial outbreak of the pandemic and have grown to account for an increasingly large portion of industry revenue. Still, this was not enough to save the industry amid the pandemic. The industry endured its largest single-year decline in 2020. A slight recovery occurred in 2022 in response to a moderate rise in print advertising, but this was short-lived.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Paper Mills Have Been Underperforming As Production For Downstream Manufacturing Loses Steam
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Downstream demand has been a historically significant factor affecting industry performance, as the majority of paper manufactured in the United States is directed toward downstream manufacturing, paper product and personal care industries. The percentage of business conducted online has been increasing as consumers turn to online substitutes for newspapers, magazines and books. Paper mills have responded by transitioning their heavy paper production activities toward additional gloss and specialty paper manufacturing as many consumers have increased their purchases of these products for digital photography purposes.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Macroeconomic Improvements Will Offer Marginal Relief to the Industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: - Corporate profit will grow during the outlook period and the growth of the percentage of business conducted online will slow down compared with the current period, both of which will likely slow the decline of industry revenue and profit. - As environmental concerns continue growing, the industry can take advantage of growth opportunities by expanding product offerings and increasing focus on sustainable methods of production. - While internet use will reduce demand for industry products, demand for labels, packaging tape and packaging papers for product boxes, all of which are made from industry products, will likely expand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Paper Mill Companies Will Continue to Contend With Volatile Input Prices
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The world price of wood pulp will continue increasing but will stabilize, making it easier for US producers to source input materials and alleviating some pressure on profit. Still, commodity prices are inherently volatile and rapid fluctuations will influence industry performance. Prices shift based on overall macroeconomic conditions and production output. Large companies will successfully handle this volatile environment, while smaller manufacturers combat liquidity pressures, making them less able to diversify resources.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: FALLING DEMAND FOR PAPER PRODUCTS IS FORCING COMPANIES TO RESTRUCTURE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The rise of digital media and electronic substitutes, in addition to the rise of foreign competition, has been siphoning demand from domestically produced paper and paper products. Industry restructuring efforts are meant to cut operating costs, decrease debt and refocus business operations on more profitable segments. Due to increased operating costs and decreased demand brought on by COVID-19, paper mill companies will continue refocusing efforts on more profitable business segments that are not industry-relevant, such as packaging.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A DEPRECIATING DOLLAR WILL OFFER A STEADY INTERNATIONAL MARKET
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the US dollar depreciates over the next few years, imports will become less attractive to domestic customers, creating breathing room for domestic paper mill companies. Major domestic markets will face less pressure to choose between expensive, superior-quality domestic products and inexpensive, inferior-quality overseas products. Similarly, exports will grow more affordable; nations with strong or growing manufacturing sectors, like Mexico or India, will benefit the most from this trend.

industry_definition: The Paper Mills industry manufactures paper in paper mills from pulp, a fibrous material derived from wood. Mill operators may manufacture their own pulp or purchase it. Industry products include paper rolls and reams, including printing and writing paper, newsprint, packaging material and household papers. These products are sold in bulk to individual consumers, businesses and downstream manufacturers that may further convert the industry's products into specialty paper products.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - steady

key_trends: Price and quality are key competition factors
Imports and digital platforms challenge domestic companies
COVID-19 exacerbated declining paper product demand
Global competition impacts the paper industry
Domtar officially purchased by Paper Excellence in December 2021
International Paper Company announced its "Building a Better IP" initiative
Stringent environmental regulations increase production costs for companies
The US Department of Commerce has imposed fees on imported coated paper from China and Indonesia
Declining demand and high operating costs are compressing industry profit
High degree of mechanization keeps wages low in the Paper Mill industry
Great Lakes charm with resources and location
Digital progress hurts the Paper Mills industry

market_segmentation.segment_description: Brokers and wholesalers serve as the middleman between paper manufacturers and end users, which include catalog publishers and commercial printers. New forms of online ordering and order tracking software systems have made it increasingly cost-effective for larger customers to buy directly from manufacturers.

End users account for specialty converters and large publishers of books, newspapers, journals, magazines, directories and other large corporations that require paper in their offices. Demand from other end users that buy directly from paper mills depends on fluctuations in corporate profit and the percentage of services conducted online. Demand from this market has increased because of rises in corporate profit levels. Consolidation among publishing industries and other downstream businesses increases demand from this market segment, as only large consumers are sizable enough to bypass wholesalers and buy paper directly from mills.

Print publishers include publication printers that act as intermediaries between manufacturers and end users. Printers source paper from manufacturers, convert and print it and then sell the finished product to the end user. Downstream demand from printing industries depends on the level of consumer demand for reading materials and prevailing levels of competition from online platforms.

products_and_services.product_description: The various types of paper produced include bleached bristols, freesheet, clay-coated, uncoated, industrial, packaging and converting papers.

These personal care products include paper towels and napkins, facial tissue, toilet paper, tampons, pads, wipes and diapers. Personal care and household products have increased due to the noncyclical demand for consumer staples. This segment is likely to continue to increase as demand for incontinence products grows in line with an aging population. Growing environmental concerns may affect certain paper household products as consumers opt for eco-friendly, reusable substitutes, such as cloth diapers and menstrual cups.

Other products produced by the paper mills industry include sulfate turpentine, wood pulp, construction paper and newsprint. Wood pulp is a pulp from wood used in making cellulose derivatives, such as paper or rayon and is the primary input for the industry. Due to the continued transition toward digital media and communication, printing and writing papers have declined as a share of revenue.

tier_1_suppliers: Wood Pulp Mills in the US
Industrial Machinery & Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing in the US
Organic Chemical Manufacturing in the US
Printing, Paper, Food, Textile & Other Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Coated & Laminated Paper Manufacturing in the US
Office Stationery Manufacturing in the US
Paper Product Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Office Stationery Wholesaling in the US
Paper Bag & Disposable Plastic Product Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Paper wholesalers purchase bulk writing paper from manufacturers and distribute them to other manufacturing industries. Wholesalers directly contribute to demand for paper and paper products from paper mill manufacturers; as wholesale demand decreases, manufacturers will endure associated revenue losses. Wholesalers account for over half of industry revenue, making them the industry's largest market.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Although the US dollar has been performing well in recent years, overall demand for paper products has gradually waned in response to the increasing number of services conducted through the internet. Declines among downstream publishing industries have been weakening overall demand for paper manufacturing consumers across the world transition from print newspapers and magazines toward digital alternatives.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Restrictions on China and Indonesia Contributes to Declining Imports
international_trade_points.trade_description: The US International Trade Commission (USITC) approving punitive duties on Chinese and Indonesian exports of specialty paper decreases the two countries' import penetration into the United States.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Strong Relations With Canada Give Way to Imports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Canada's proximity to the United States affords both countries a long-standing trading relationship, which has been strengthened by continued bipartisan trade efforts such as the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). Many US companies have also taken advantage of Canada's vast timber resources, causing several major mills to have headquarters operations in the country.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The Largest Destination for Industry Exports is Canada
international_trade_points.trade_description: Industry trade with Canada benefits from advantageous trade conditions with the United States through the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). This agreement, which replaced NAFTA, dramatically reduced tariffs on goods flowing among neighboring countries and boosted total trade activity.

international_trade_points.trade_title: A Depreciating Dollar Will Cause Exports to Account for a Higher Share of Industry Revenue Over the Outlook Period
international_trade_points.trade_description: A decreasing trade-weighted index (TW), which measures the strength of the US dollar relative to the currencies of its major trading partners, will mitigate industry export declines as domestically produced goods become comparatively less expensive for foreign customers.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has traditionally been a major pulp and papermaking area due to close access to raw materials and large markets in the eastern United States.

Paper mills need fresh water for cleaning and cooling machines, which is what lures companies to this region. Proximity to large Canadian timber stocks makes this region more attractive as it gives establishments a greater opportunity to expand.

This region is attractive to paper mill investors because of its convenient access to customers from major metropolitan cities. Major highway routes allow for easy transportation to the Canadian timber market.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Clean Water Act and Resource Conservation and Recovery Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: The industry is responsible for ensuring that paper mill companies adhere to protocols pertaining to the appropriate disposal of liquid and solid waste to maintain clean and healthy waters. This adds significantly to individual producers' administrative and environmental requirements, which may increase production costs and reduce manufacturing productivity.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Safe Drinking Water Act and Clean Air Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Safe Drinking Water Act requires that any dumping of spent water will impose only minimal polluting effects on local aquifers and will not have any significant effect on local drinking water. The Clean Air Act is designed to protect the country's air from the damaging effect of smog and vaporized pollutants by establishing limits to air pollutants such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxides, sulfur oxides and other particulate matter.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Comprehensive Environmental Response Compensation and Liability Act and Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Comprehensive Environmental Response Compensation and Liability Act authorizes the US Environmental Protection Agency to respond and potentially levy fines to companies that release hazardous substances that may endanger public health, welfare or the environment. The Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act requires businesses that use, manufacture or are in contact with toxic substances to have open communication channels with emergency services.

In response to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidance, various levels of regulation have been implemented in the United States and overseas to discourage public gatherings, large events or crowded, unsafe work environments. Restrictions continue to be eliminated in 2024 due to the widespread distribution of the COVID-19 vaccine.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The paper mills industry is in the decline stage of its life cycle.
The industry faces high but steady competition.

factors_decreased_barrier.barrier_description: Paper mills must follow strict environmental protection guidelines imposed by the US Environmental Protection Agency and state and local government regulations.

basis_points.basis_description: In the Paper Mills industry, companies compete heavily on price and quality, with access to affordable raw materials and economies of scale being crucial advantages.

The industry faces significant external competition from cheaper imported products, particularly from Canada, Mexico and China and from the increasing popularity of digital media replacing traditional paper products.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Falling industry demand is forcing players out of the market.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases vary with the price of wood pulp
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases as a share of revenue have decreased over the past five years. Other costs and purchases represent the two largest costs for paper mill companies. These include major input and operational expenses, such as

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Machines are doing most of the work, boosting other costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Other costs as a share of revenue have increased over the past five years. Paper mills have a low labor dependency compared with similar paper product manufacturing industries because of a high degree of mechanization in the industry.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases are the industry's second-largest cost segment
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases as a share of revenue have decreased over the past five years. Historically, industry profit has been low for various reasons, including a high share of purchases and relatively low value-added products sold in the industry.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Paper mills are capital-intensive since they require purchasing or leasing large equipment and a warehouse that can accommodate large machinery.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Economic Uncertainty Plays a Big Role
volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue volatility is primarily influenced by major shifts in the macroeconomic environment and changes in the exchange rate. Demand for paper products tends to be cyclical, so, during periods of economic prosperity, companies may need more office supplies for new employees or choose to spend more on print advertising as demand for paper products grows. Over the past five years, revenue has declined steadily, although the COVID-19 outbreak exacerbated revenue volatility in 2020.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Substitutes and Input Prices Have Disrupted Growth
volatility_points.volatility_description: The Paper Mills industry endures a moderate level of revenue volatility, largely due to the industry's consistently fading relevance amid an increasingly paper-free global economy. As developing economies increase their paper production capacities, revenue has increasingly dealt with pressure from import penetration. Growing environmental concerns and the volatile nature of input prices (wood pulp) have negatively impacted demand for paper products.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: - Byproducts and waste materials from the paper production process are used to generate renewable energy through waste-to-energy programs. - To reduce their environmental impact, paper mills are implementing water recycling and purification systems to reduce water consumption and discharge. - Paper mills are investing in renewable energy sources like solar and wind power to achieve carbon neutrality and offset their carbon emissions.

- The recycling process is becoming more efficient as paper mills adopt cutting-edge recycling technologies that enable them to recover a higher percentage of fibers from used paper. - To reduce their reliance on external sources of recycled fibers, some paper mills are implementing closed-loop recycling systems that collect and reuse their own waste paper internally. - To lessen their impact on the environment, paper mills are investing in research and development to develop eco-friendly paper products like those made from alternative fibers or agricultural residues.

FAQs.question: How have imports from low-wage countries like China and Mexico impacted your operations?
FAQs.answer: At the end of the previous decade, China claimed the United States' long-held title of the world's largest paper manufacturing industry. Therefore, the industry has historically struggled in the face of rising import penetration from low-wage countries.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Demand for wood pulp is closely tied to producing paper and paper-based products. Economic conditions impact sectors such as publishing, packaging, and manufacturing, all of which contribute to the demand for paper. Businesses tend to produce and consume more paper-based goods when the economy is strong.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: The rising world price of wood pulp has had a negative impact on profit margins in recent years.

FAQs.question: Is your company located near important suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Paper mills benefit from locating close to upstream wood pulp suppliers and downstream consumer markets and wholesalers. Paper mills with integrated pulp and paper operations have the strategic advantage of being near supplies.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in technology like 3D printing to establish a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: Changes in technology have not played a significant role in this industry in recent years. Current technological innovations focus on streamlining operations and inventory management.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Wages' revenue share has remained relatively steady despite slight investments in automation.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Many industry associations support the industry, including the American Forest and Paper Association.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations, such as energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Large paper mills generally have in-house compliance teams that keep them up-to-date with regulation. Meanwhile, small paper mills rely more on industry associations for regulatory information.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for the seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Demand for paper is relatively stable throughout the calendar year, limiting the seasonality of cash flow.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your customers renew their contracts?
FAQs.answer: Due to the growing proliferation of electronic correspondence and other technology advancements, demand from downstream customers has waned in recent years.

FAQs.question: Do you produce and supply your own wood pulp? If not, do you have any contracts for this input?
FAQs.answer: Contracts for the supply of wood pulp will ensure that a paper producer has access to the raw materials required to manufacture paper. Many of the larger industry operators have integrated pulp and paper mills; producing their own wood pulp allows them to streamline operations and cut costs.

FAQs.question: Have you invested heavily in automation? What affect does automation have on your profit?
FAQs.answer: Installation of modern technology to improve plant efficiency and reduce costs will not only give a producer a financial advantage but also a marketing advantage through the use of clean technology. Technological innovation will be crucial to this industry's success in the coming years as demand shifts toward online and environmentally friendly substitutes.

FAQs.question: How much do you invest in research and development? Have you developed any unique products or enhanced efficiency?
FAQs.answer: Research and development will maximize the possibility of developing higher quality products with faster production schedules as well managing inventory and order fulfillment.

FAQs.question: How do you promote products that cater to online users?
Have you had to pare down operations due to the proliferation of the internet?
FAQs.answer: The widespread use of online media has resulted in a net reduction in stationery, letters, business forms, envelopes and other paper products. This trend has reduced downstream demand for the Paper Mills industry, adversely affecting revenue.

FAQs.question: Does your revenue follow trends in corporate profit?
FAQs.answer: Corporate profit growth typically improves business sentiment, encourages business expansion and increases demand for the industry's products.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your revenue is derived from corporate clients, and from what industries?
What proportion of your revenue is derived from manufacturers of paper products? Do you have any long-term contracts with these manufacturers?
FAQs.answer: Paper product manufacturing industries are significant users of paper mill products. An increase in activity and revenue for these downstream industries indicates growing demand for paper rolls and reams, which will positively influence mills.
